user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarSignal:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarSignal(osal_id_t var_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CondVarSignal_Impl(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarSignal:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_CondVarSignal_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_cond_signal(&impl->cv);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No controlling expressions in the provided code are invariant. The only conditional statements are: (1) if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) in OS_CondVarSignal — return_code is assigned from OS_ObjectIdGetById so is not a compile-time or invariant constant; (2) in OS_ObjectIdGetById: if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS) after OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) after OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, and if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS) before OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel — all depend on function return values and are not invariant; (3) in OS_CondVarSignal_Impl: if (status != 0) where status = pthread_cond_signal(...) — depends on runtime return of pthread_cond_signal. There are no for/while/do-while loops or switch statements with constant controlling expressions, and no do-while with an integer constant expression used as the sole controlling expression. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 in the supplied code.
